data.question: What is the association constant (Ka) of the axle 12+ with DB24C8 in MeCN as measured by 1H NMR spectroscopy?
Which metal ions were used to form the 3D metal-organic framework materials containing [2]rotaxanes?
data.answer: Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, and Yb

data.question: What geometry does the YbIII center adopt in the 3D polyrotaxane with a distinctly different solid-state structure?
How does the stability of materials 3-6 and 7 compare according to thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements?
data.answer: Both sorts of materials show similar stability

data.question: What is the role of the longer N-oxide axle in the structure of the metal-organic frameworks?
data.answer: It results in an elongation of the metal-metal separation which creates an expanded cavity that can accommodate the girth of the [2]rotaxane ligand.

data.question: What is the significance of the [2]rotaxane's ability to fit through the pores of the metal-organic frameworks?
data.answer: It indicates that interpenetration of these rotaxane nets is a possibility since the openings created are large enough for these uncommonly 'wide' ligands.

data.question: What was the highest order structure attainable with the dynamic ligand and d block transition-metal ions before the introduction of the bis(N-oxide) analogue axle 12+?
Why was a three-dimensional (3D) network not possible with the original dipyridinium ligand?
data.answer: Due to the crowding occurring on placing six of these sterically demanding ligands around a single metal ion.

data.question: How were the 3D metal-organic framework materials formed using lanthanide ions?
data.answer: Through simple room-temperature, metalâ€“ligand self-assembly (crystal engineering) reactions.

data.question: What was the outcome of using a metal ion with a slightly smaller radius, YbIII, compared to TbIII?
data.answer: It yielded another 3D polyrotaxane but with a distinctly different solid-state structure.

data.question: What does the presence of a chloride ion in the structures of compounds 3-7 indicate?
data.answer: It is attributed to small amounts of this anion in the bulk sample of axle 12+ since during work up 12+ is subjected to column chromatography in which one of the solvents is aqueous NH4Cl before anion exchange to OTf.

data.question: What does the planar tessellation of a five-coordinate node into a 2D network in the structure of compound 7 demonstrate?
data.answer: It demonstrates that each N-oxide ligand can 'bend' at the Yb-O-N linkage, resulting in a [3/4,5] net comprising alternating triangles and squares linked through five-connected nodes.

data.question: Is the [2]rotaxane motif employed in the construction of 3D metal-organic frameworks?
Was a three-dimensional network achieved with the original dipyridinium ligand and d block transition-metal ions?
Does the YbIII center in the 3D polyrotaxane adopt a six-coordinate geometry?
Are the [2]rotaxanes initially formed with strong covalent interactions?
Is the 3D metal ligand framework intact until temperatures above 240 8C?
Can the design of soft materials with interlocked components be expanded to include pyridinium N-oxide axles and crown-ether wheels?
Is it impossible to create fully 3D structures in which every linker is a pyridinium-based rotaxane?
Is interpenetration of the rotaxane nets not a possibility due to the size of the openings?
